video.title: Linux Operating System - Crash Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the basics of the Linux Operating System in this crash course for beginners. Linux is a clone of the UNIX operating system, so understanding one is understanding the other. The goal is for you to get a full understanding of how the Linux OS works. If you're still using Windows or Mac OS, you can still learn Linux using a virtual machine.

✏️ Course from KeepItTechie. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCP2bshADPrVMoNrdJvZEQzw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:08:09) Install Linux
⌨️ (0:29:43) Desktop Environment
⌨️ (0:41:18) Terminal
⌨️ (0:49:25) Working with Directories
⌨️ (1:15:49) Working with Files
⌨️ (1:34:49) Working with File Content
⌨️ (1:51:14) Linux File Structure
⌨️ (2:03:68) System Information
⌨️ (2:15:42) Networking
⌨️ (2:20:10) Linux Package Manager
⌨️ (2:34:10) Text Editor
⌨️ (2:46:56) Outro

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: Robert E.
replies.text:
So, most people turn on their comp and their OS (windows, linux, whatever) eventually loads.  This is because pressing the power button basically initiates BIOS on the motherboard and then BIOS initiates the OS on the hard drive.  

With a "Virtual Box" the OS isn't on the hard drive, but some other media (typically a Flashdrive/USB stick or a DVD).  So you press the power button, that initiates the BIOS on the motherboard,  and then the BIOS initiates the OS *on the virtualbox* (e.g. flashdrive/USB stick), completely bypassing the hard drive altogether.

With this setup, you can forever use Linux on the Virtualbox and never truly install it on your comp, OR, from the virtualbox, you can then install Linux on your harddrive (which is sort of synonymous saying that your installing it on your comp).

In this situation,  the OS the computer is running is not Windows, or MacOS, or whatever, it's the Linux distro (e.g. Ubuntu, RedHat, etx.) on the Virtualbox media.

You can install Linux (or really ANY OS) on a computer in addition to Windows (for example installing multiple harddrives each with its own OS or one large harddrive with correct "partitions"), but regardless of the method, with this type of setup, you can only boot into one OS at a time.*

*when properly done, each time your comp starts up, you go into BIOS and select which OS you want to load, or you can sort of throw a tiny program inbetween the BIOS to OS sequence, a program like GRUB for example, so after the BIOS starts, it starts GRUB and then GRUB says, "hey, user, you got more than one OS on this thing.  Which one would you like to boot into today?"

ss (netstat)

topLevelComment.author: 04ELY
topLevelComment.text: I know it's for the algorithm and I will thank you anyway but people, there's a distinction between the Linux OS and the shells. These programming related channels will obviously only teach you the command line interface but this is not Linux as a whole, this is just a part of it used in software development etc. Please stop giving the image of Linux = bash. I know dozens of people who think linux is the "command line operating system" similar to something like DOS. It may have the best command line interface but it's just a feature among the many. It has much more than the command line. It's something you can use. Anyway, thanks for making the course, will be helpful for software beginners but I clearly dislike the title.

topLevelComment.author: Joseph Steinhauser
topLevelComment.text:
2:07:55 To show "ps" list of processes, it is more useful to use "ps -eaf" rather than "ps -A" to show memory use, CPU time, how long ago started, user-ID, and more.
This usually outputs several pages of text, so you may also want to pipe it through grep, less, awk, or sort+head, to focus on the processes you want.
The "pstree" command will show which procs are related to each other, as parent & child, in a branch/indented tree.
For a quick screen of the heaviest process load on your machine... use command "top" which shows top CPU use, updated every 10 seconds. (press "q" to quit)

replies.author: Tanmay Panadi
replies.text:
Use what works for your workflow. 
there are pros and cons to everything.

IMO.

linux is for people who like their privacy and support open-source software .

it just works on any hardware let it be 10 years old or new.
you can customize the system for what you want to do and how you want to do it no restrictions at all. 
it has really great speeds when ever I want to move large no of small files or just a big file around. 
the network stack and options are very nice when using it for torrents and working with files.

The Linux filesystems like BTRFs and Ext4, ZFS is more advance and newer than NTFS. it is build with multiple users in mind.
ZFS and BTRFS files backups and restore functions that actually work unlike windows.

windows is really great for Adobe suite and gaming point of view.

topLevelComment.author: Hans Müller
topLevelComment.text:
Good that he talked a bit about Stallman. But he should have explained what free software actually means.
Free has multiple meanings in english and in this case, it is about rights. It's not free as in free beer. Thus, sometimes free software is called libre software.
Stallman recommends to watch his TED talk in which he explained the importance of free software.
So yeah. Btw. if you are a new user you might want to join a community (forum, reddit, chat platform). By regularly checking a community, you will see what other people share and thus you might learn new things every few days. I for instance am active in the Linux Gaming community on Matrix and Discord (tho discord is not a good platfom and unfree software..).
